Album info
1. A Foggy Day (5:35)
(Gershwin-Gershwin) Chappel & Co., Inc.-ASCAP

2. Drums (5:34)
(Roach-Mingus) Jazz Workshop-BMI

3. Haitian Fight Song (5:24)
(Charles Mingus) Chaz Mar-BMI

4. Lady Bird (5:54)
(Tadd Dameron) Music Sales Corp.-ASCAP

5. I'll Remember April (13:10)
(Raye-DePaul-Johnson) MCA, Inc./ Rytvoc Music-ASCAP

6. Love Chant (7:52)
(Charles Mingus) Chaz Mar-BMI

Eddie Bert - trombone
George Barrow - tenor saxophone
Mal Waldron - piano
Charles Mingus - bass
Willie Jones - drums
Max Roach - drums ("Drums", "I'll Remember April" only)

Recorded at CafÃ© Bohemia, New York City; December 23, 1955.

Digital mastering, 1990 - Phil De Lancie (Fantasy Studios, Berkeley)

Fantasy Records
Fantasy, Inc.
Tenth and Parker
Berkeley, CA 94710
All rights reserved.



"Back in those long ago days when bop had died and modern jazz was fading and Jazz at the Philharmonic was just beginning to build an audience, Dizzy Gillespie made a speech one night about bass players. He listed them all, inventoried their talents and ended with a flat statement. "There are only two geniuses of the bass; Oscar Pettiford and Charlie Mingus." Oscar is gone, but Mingus is still with us and even though he seems better known today as a composer and innovater than as a bass soloist, the truth of what Gillespie says is evident in every album Mingus makes. This one is no exception.

The bass is hard, for even the virtuoso players, to make into a solo instrument. Audiences resist it. But not when Mingus plays it. And of course when Mingus does solo, he makes the whole thing look so easy and simple that it's frightening.

Mingus, through the years from "Mingus Fingers" down to last night's speech, has been struggling to break the stereotype of jazz musician and entertainer and emerge in the eyes of the audience and the ears of the listeners as what he really is: a complex personality with many facets, all resting on the hard core of his musical genius.

Today, even though he is the bass soloist supreme, he is acquiring more stature every year (whether or not he seeks it) as a composer and serious musician (because jazz is, as Ellington among others has insisted, a serious music).

Mingus' stature is growing constantly by an inevitable, almost automatic process now, as the integuement of his compositions, his albums, his appearances and his own personality deposit layer after layer and add to the original.

The American society into which jazz was born has made it almost impossible for the serious jazz musician to be taken seriously for his music. Stereotype and misconception have made Duke Ellington a strangely perverse and hidden genius, with dozens of skins to shed before he stands out real, except in his music. Prejudice, musical and otherwise, have done the same sort of thing to Monk with a different, but none the less deep-set effect.

Of the three - Duke, Monk and Mingus who comprise jazz' major line of composition - only Mingus has struck back verbally and musically in a tough-minded musical rebuttal.

Curiously, for such a compassionate man, Mingus' music can be light and airy and filled with wit. At times it can be downright comic in intent and execution; at other times, hard to tell whether to laugh or cry.

But never, in any single thing he has ever done, has Mingus been dull. You may like his music or you may not like it. But you cannot ignore it, anymore than you can ignore him. It throbs with artistic honesty, with musical imagination and is laced with surprise.

This album has elements of all of it. "A Foggy Day", for instance, is (like "I'll Remember April") an example of how Mingus can take a tune that has been played to death, draw out of it new meanings and reassemble them in new ways. The unexpected always plays a part in what he does. "Haitian Fight Song" is another example, with the blues this time as the starting point.

Max Roach, who with Mingus has assaulted the bastions of complacency, special privilege and musical ignorance, has done some of his best work on records in association with Mingus. He is heard here on two tracks, the exciting "Drums" and the ballad, "I'll Remember April". Willie Jones drums on the other tracks. George Barrow plays tenor, Mal Waldron is the pianist, and Eddie Bert is the trombonist.

The recording was made on location at the Bohemia in New York City and it possesses that special "live" quality that comes only from such sessions.

Two of the Mingus compositions on this LP, "Haitian Fight Song" and "Love Chant", are fascinating to play one after the other and I think they indicate the universality of man's struggle. In combination with other of Mingus' compositions, they seem to be part of some longer work.

Nothing that is said here can really help them, though. Music is its own explanation, its own argument, its own statement. All the written word can do is urge you to listen. The rest is up to you."

-Ralph J. Gleason
